text: [Music]
in Thailand Valentine's Day coincides
with an important Buddhist holiday so
many of the protesters who see Buddhism
is central to their campaign took time
off to commemorate it the Thai police
had other ideas after three months of
retreating they decided to take back
some of the ground they'd lost but very
cautiously past experience has taught
them to expect tough and occasionally
armed resistance their target here was
this camp headquarters for a group which
has been in the forefront of previous
clashes with the police but seemed
strangely empty now these impressive
fortifications have been built up around
the Prime Minister's office but one of
the most hardcore groups in the protest
movement and the police haven't dared
approach them but today there's just a
few people defending it and now hundreds
and hundreds of police is 50 metres away
who certainly got the numbers to retake
this area but they want to ours though
they left it to the handful of remaining
protesters who seemed unsure whether
they should resist negotiate we'll just
sing in other places there was
resistance and the government stuck to
its tactic of avoiding bloodshed so in
the end it didn't gain much but by
lunchtime the main Royal Boulevard in
Bangkok was under police control for the
first time this year it hadn't been
defended at all for weeks this had been
a riot of tents and roadside stalls
profiting from the thousands of
protesters who'd staked their claim to
this historic piece of Bangkok for the
stallholders it was now time to pack up
and move on it was a small but symbolic
victory for a government which hasn't
had much in the way of good news for a
long time Jonathan had BBC news Bangkok
